Yes, putting public pressure on corporations can be an effective way to encourage them to adopt more ethical and responsible practices. This is because corporations rely on their public reputation and brand image to maintain consumer loyalty and trust, which can be a powerful motivator for them to take steps to address public concerns. 

To build public pressure and hold corporations accountable, a range of tactics can be used. For example, consumer boycotts, online activism, and public rallies can help draw attention to corporate practices and demand change. Additionally, leveraging the power of social media and other digital platforms can help to amplify public calls for accountability and transparency.

Finally, it is important to recognize that consumers and other stakeholders play an essential role in driving corporate accountability. By selecting companies that prioritize ethical and socially responsible practices, and by supporting advocacy efforts, public pressure can have a positive impact on corporate behavior and result in changes in the way they operate.
